stem: A 68-year-old client presents with chest pain. Based on the documentation in the Serial Cardiac Marker & EKG Log, which interpretation of the trends is most accurate?

options.text: The client has progressed from myocardial ischemia to an evolving anterior wall MI.
The client's cardiac markers are peaking, indicating that the MI is resolving.
The initial normal troponin at 0 hour rules out any myocardial injury.
The development of pathological Q-waves indicates that the tissue is salvageable.

rationale.correct: The documentation shows a classic progression of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The initial 0-hour assessment showed ischemia (ST depression/normal labs). By 6-12 hours, the troponins have spiked (0.84 -> 4.22) and the EKG shows ST elevation in the anterior leads (V2-V4), followed by pathological Q-waves. This trajectory confirms an evolving and completing anterior wall MI.
clinicalPearls: Troponin is the GOLD STANDARD for MI because it is highly specific and rises within 3-6 hours of injury.
ST Elevation (STEMI) indicates active injury; Q-waves indicate permanent tissue death (infarction).
Leads V2, V3, V4 represent the Anterior wall (supplied by the Left Anterior Descending - LAD artery).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a normal initial troponin rules out an MI.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always repeat markers every 3-6 hours. It takes time for the necrotic muscle proteins to leak into the general circulation.
